measured_by: 24-task slider preference scale (0–100) comparing algorithm vs. human recommendations
justification: “Participants were then presented with the same set of 24 tasks … asked to indicate how likely you are to follow the recommendation a computer algorithm … 0 represents a very strong preference for the algorithm; 100 represents a very strong preference for the human.”

measured_by: Mutual-fund choice between robo-advisor recommendation and human advisor recommendation
justification: “Which mutual fund would you invest in? Omega (recommended by robo-advisor) or Kappa (recommended by human advisor).”

measured_by: Song selection choice between algorithm-recommended song and musician-recommended song
justification: “Participants were told that one song will be recommended by an algorithm … the other song will be recommended by a musician … asked to select the song that you think you will like more.”

measured_by: Dental-treatment choice between option endorsed by dentist vs. computer algorithm
justification: “They were asked to choose between two treatments … One treatment was recommended by the dentist and the other was recommended by the algorithm.”

measured_by: Slider (0–100) indicating preference for stock recommended by human expert vs. robo-advisor
justification: “Please indicate below your relative preference of investment in the two funds … 0: invest all in Omega (robo-advisor)… 100: invest all in Kappa (human expert).”

measured_by: 4-item Small Self scale (e.g., ‘I feel small’; ‘I feel the presence of something greater than me’)
justification: “Small Self. Participants completed a measure of small self using responses to the following items: ‘Right now, I feel small,’ ‘I feel the presence of something greater than me,’ … (α = .79).”

measured_by: 4-item Human Imperfection scale (e.g., ‘All people have flaws’)
justification: “Human Imperfection. Participants completed a measure of human imperfection using responses to the following items: ‘We are all imperfect in many ways,’ ‘All people have flaws,’ … (α = .92).”
“State Authenticity … participants responded with the items: ‘authentic,’ ‘like myself,’ and ‘fake’ (reverse-coded; α = .82).”

measured_by: 3-item Dental Risk scale (likelihood, severity, coping with health consequences)
justification: “Participants then answered three questions designed to assess what the authors referred to as ‘dental risk’. Specifically, they indicated their level of agreement with three statements … The responses to the three statements were averaged.”

measured_by: Determinism scale (e.g., ‘The future has already been determined by fate’)
justification: “beliefs about the extent to which the world is deterministic (e.g., ‘The future has already been determined by fate’).”

measured_by: Ratings of 20 emotion words on 1–5 scale (Not at all – Extremely)
justification: “their current feelings, assessed by asking them to rate the extent to which they were feeling 20 different emotions … Measure (3) used a scale anchored at 1 = Not at all and 5 = Extremely.”

measured_by: Ratings of 20 emotion words on 1–5 scale (Not at all – Extremely)
justification: Same 20-emotion battery was analysed for negative mood as noted: “In the original study, there were no significant effects of God prime on positive mood, negative mood …”

measured_by: 0–100 slider item ‘strength of belief in God’
justification: “participants reported … strength of belief in god (0 = not at all believe, 100 = strongly believe).”

measured_by: Single-item 7-point religiosity question (‘Overall, how religious do you consider yourself to be?’)
justification: “we also added a measure of religiosity using responses to the following item, ‘Overall, how religious do you consider yourself to be?’ Participants responded on a 7-point scale.”

measured_by: Single-item manipulation-check (‘extent to which they thought about God’, 1–5)
justification: “participants completed a manipulation check that assessed the extent to which they thought about God during the study (1 = not at all, 5 = a great deal).”
